posts.name: James Karczewski
posts.cooked: I’m currently making an electrical guide for FRC. I know that some teams do electrical work a bit differently so, are there any suggestions on what to add to it or any components you want on it? (I will be posting it once it is finished)

posts.name: Abi
posts.cooked: Use of ferrules to keep wire ends neat and WAGO inline connectors as opposed to Anderson’s/others

posts.name: James Karczewski
posts.cooked: My team still uses Anderson Powerpoles, but for prototyping, and thinner gauge wire (such as CAN) WAGO inline connectors are the best choice

posts.name: Jeremy Martinez
posts.cooked:
Definitely ferrules for all wires going into WAGO connectors that aren’t the lever lock type.  We use the inline lever lock type for most smaller gage and Andersons for the motor wires just because its easier and faster for swap out and testing purposes.  We also use a lot of zip tie pads to clean up the wire routing.  Especially since we use a lot of single wires instead of cables.  Cables add more useless weight in my opinion.

General rule for our electrical team is the larger the wire we try to keep those runs shorter.  You would be surprised how much weight is in the wiring.

Clean wiring for FRC is very tricky and hard to teach in the short build time but very helpful when it comes to competition and quick repairs.  We get compliments every year from FTAs and inspectors on our clean wiring.  It takes a lot of planning especially when the mechanical team says “we can throw the electrical where ever it fits” and coding team wants it done yesterday so they can test their code!  We have been laying out our electrical system in CAD for the past five years.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mentor of FRC 2405 & 6094 FTC 11531,18092 & 8932 Alum of 1254

posts.custom_user_title: Mentor of FRC 2405 & 6094 FTC 11531,18092 & 8932 Alum of 1254

posts.cooked:
Just going to put this out here again. When the ctre pdp was released they spent a considerable amount of time trying to convince teams NOT to use ferrules on the main pdp power ports due to to the MASSIVE reduction in current carrying capability it causes. ferrules are great for sensor wires but nothing bigger than 16 gauge in an frc application.

EDIT: Also since the data sheet for the connectors used on the rev pdb specifics that if ferrules are used the wire should be considered 2 gauges smaller for rating purposes i could see a really roundabout argument that since the 12 gauge is derated with ferrules it’s no longer legal for a 40 amp breaker.

posts.name: James Karczewski
posts.cooked:
It’s the same on my team. the mechanical subteam has no standards when it comes to electrical. They used zipties as a battery strap, they put 2 batteries on top of each other and used a rachet strap to hold them down, they’ve dusted metal shavings all over the electrical system, the whole 9 yards. Everything that is close to or is a big no no to me, has already happened in the previous 4 weeks of build season.

Other thatn that, yes cable management is very important. We use wire channel to sorta help clean things up on the electrical pannel and zip tie pads (we call them sticky squares) to keep wires out of unwanted areas where they could get snagged or ripped.

I’ll have to add this.

posts.name: James Karczewski
posts.cooked: True, but I’d say that ferrules aren’t needed for anything over 20 or 18  AWG. Ferrules for 16 and even 12 AWG exist, and we have them, but I don’t see the need for Ferrules that large. If the bare-stranded wire doesn’t hold in the connector, just re-strip the wire. Plus the wires for the Viair air compressor we use are 16 AWG and they don’t fit well, with ferrules on them, in the REV Pneumatic Hub compressor port.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
Here are some of the things we on 6328 have previously shared regarding electrical, from our last few build threads:

From 2020/2021: General 6328 best practices - Covers a lot of basics and some of how our thinking has evolved.

From 2022: Main power crimps (and how they can go wrong) and debugging frame faults

Haven’t done a 2023 post on electrical yet but I expect we’ll have some things to share soon.

I think it’s important to point out that there are multiple areas of electrical where teams choose different standards/practices and there is not One Right Answer - witness some of the endless threads on CD about some of these topics, and even discussion in this thread so far.  Many of us have strongly held opinions based on our own experiences and guide our teams accordingly, but others may prioritize different things, have different constraints, or have had different experiences and so go a different way.  If you delve into these areas you can either take the approach of “here is what we do but there are other good alternatives” or if you’re trying to be more exhaustive, “here are the various alternatives and what we understand the tradeoffs of each to be”.

That said, there are very definitely wrong ways to do things that one should never see on a robot, and any sort of electrical guide should encourage generally accepted good practices and discourage the bad ones.

posts.name: topgun
posts.cooked:
Chaz_Karchezzy:

My team still uses Anderson Powerpoles, but for prototyping, and thinner gauge wire (such as CAN ) WAGO inline connectors are the best choice

you forgot the words “for me and my team”.

Every team is different and teams have different standards because of their resources, purchasing choices, mentor experience, etc.  Judging by the number of threads on this topic over the years, the choice of electrical connectors is quite varied.

The standard on my old team for thinner wires were locking Molex connectors.  Easy to use, lightweight, and they don’t come apart in rough FRC play.

https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/molex/0050579403/115034

https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/molex/0701070002/210969
It’s a given, but never forget the tried and true tug test.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Yes. The tug test is a crucial part of the quality control procedures that ensure your robot does not sit dead on the field.

It is also helpful to select people who have demonstrated that they are meticulous and have demonstrated good attention to detail in their work to do the work on the electrical (and pneumatic) system. Not everyone has these qualities and they are very difficult to teach/learn just like not everyone has the right qualities to be a good driver.

posts.cooked: You’re probably already planning to add it if not already, but some wire management and organization techniques would be good I think

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
bbonner:

not One Right Answer

I decided to join the ferrule culture war and read several articles including this Phoenix Contact article. They present a thoughtful discussion and say

Users have to make their own decision here.

and further say

ferrules offer many advantages – both mechanically and electrically

Bare stranded wire can conform to the terminal better (possibly CTRE ’s argument) but may squish out thus reducing contact in some terminals.

Oxidation on the surface of strands increases resistance. Properly compressed ferrules break those many hard shells, prevent re-oxidation and thus reduce resistance.

Mechanical ease of installation with ferrules is a tremendous benefit in industry (paying the hourly rate of highly trained and capable installers) and more so a huge benefit to novice student installers (just starting to get indoctrinated about an unfamiliar or not fully comprehended concept that careful, quality work matters).

posts.name: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!
posts.cooked: CM, not true.  If teams used WAGO ferrules crimped with the WAGO crimp tool, the PDP did not need to be derated for current.  Using other ferrules and non standard crimps were the same as using solid wire and that did cause a derating of one wire size.  This was due to the contact area inside the PDP WAGO and the surface area within the contact.  As always, check the documentation on the parts you use to be sure you are using them as intended.
posts.display_username: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!
